loans.use: to buy rice seeds and fertilizer for growing his dry-season rice

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
This is Mary Jane, 39, resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. Her husband is Tyron, a factory worker, and father to her only child. She and her husband manage their own household while operating the business. Mary Jane works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Mary Jane operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, Philippine Pesos (PHP) 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She makes money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling items individually. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Aside from this she also sells cooked food to make additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue to operate her business, she is requesting a PHP 18,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Mary Jane hopes her business grows into a mini-grocery and dreams of giving her child a good and high quality education thanks to all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can, she also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Tsetsegmaa

texts.en:
Tsetsegmaa is 34-years-old and lives with her husband and son in a ger (mongolian yurt) in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. Her husband helps with her business and her son is staying at home due to the college fee. 

She started her cafeteria business in 2008 by renting it. Now she has a contract with many companies serving lunch. Her foods are tasty, largely portioned and cheap. However, she can't handle all the customers due to the space of the cafe. She has a half built extension of a cafe and she wants to finish it. 

She is requesting 2,500,000 MNT to finish her cafe's extension. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says,"My business is going great however I couldn't pay my son's college fee. If I build this extension, my son would be able to go to the college."

loans.use: to finish her cafe's extension.

loans.name: Horn

texts.en: Horn, 52, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Horn is a farmer and raises animals at home. Horn is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work in the city. By doing so, her family is able to decrease expenses on public transportation. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
This is Grace, 58, a resident of Bacoor, Cavite City, Philippines. Her husband, Alejandro, is her business partner, and father to her three children. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Grace operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Aside from this she also oversees their Jeepney unit (a public utility vehicle) that gives them additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1000 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 26,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Grace hopes her business grows in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Undraa

texts.en:
Undraa is 50-years-old and lives with her husband in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Ulaanbaatar dictrict, Mongolia. Her husband is a retired old man. 

She started her grocery retailing business in 2001. Her business is stable. Now that her kids are grown and educated, she wants to concentrate on her business. She is planning to expand her workspace and sell additional products. She is a hardworking and diligent woman who says, "My business has served me well. My kids are educated and independent. Now it's time to concentrate on my business." 

She is requesting 1,500,000 MNT to buy consrtuction materials to repair her store and purchase some grocery products.

loans.use: to buy consrtuction materials to repair her store.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is 51 years old and has only one child who is now 30 years old and had settled down and married but still lives with her. At Maria's age, she is thankful for having three lovely grandchildren.

Maria sells fruits and vegetables at the market. She also sells eggs, onions, and vinegars. Maria rents a stall in the market. She has been running her business for almost 10 years and earns about P2,000 each month. She utilizes it well for electric bills, meals, and sometimes providing daily snacks and allowances of her grandchildren. 

Maria is now asking for P25,000 to have additional funds to buy more eggs, cabbage, and tomatoes to sell in her store.

Maria's goal is to also own a stall in the market because paying for the rental is an additional expense for her.

loans.use: to buy more eggs, cabbage, and tomatoes to sell in her store.

loans.name: Tuis

texts.en:
Tuis is 24-years-old and lives with his wife in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bayan-ulgii province, Mongolia. His wife is unemployed. 

He started his taxi service business in 2010 using his own car. His car is old and rusty therefore nobody wants to sit in his car. He sold his car and is planning to buy a newer car to run his business properly. However he is lacking 1,000,000 MNT to buy a newer car. 

He is an educated young man who says,"I am the only one with the income in the family. Therefore I have to work hard and do everything I can."

loans.use: to buy a newer car.

loans.name: Vanna

texts.en:
Vanna, 43, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Vanna is a farmer and raises animals at home. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver. 

Vanna is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work in the city. By doing so, her family will be able to decrease expenses for public transportation.
 
In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.name: Silan

texts.en:
Silan, 35, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Silan sells kitchen utensils and her husband is a teacher at the public school. 

Silan is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more kitchen utensils to resell. By doing so, her family will be able to generate more income.
 
In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more kitchen utensils to resell.

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
40-year-old Charito earns a living selling dried fish and also dealing in Avon and Natasha products in her community. She is married and has school-aged children. Charito runs her business in Baclayon, Bohol. She works hard to support her family.

Charito has requested this loan to buy more dried fish and personal products to sell. She hopes to acquire her own vehicle someday so transporting dried fish would be easier.

loans.use: to buy more dried fish and personal products to sell.

loans.name: Metodia

texts.en:
Metodia is 62 years old and married. She runs a sari-sari store in Baclayon, Bohol. Metodia sells various items like soft drinks, chips, and coffee. Aside from the store, Metodia also provides catering and tailoring services to her community. 

Metodia requested this loan to buy more items to sell such as soft drinks and canned goods. She plans to expand her store in the future.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell such as soft drinks and canned goods.

loans.name: Jeanne Claire

texts.en:
Jeanne Claire is married and has three children.  She lives in San Jose, Baggao, Cagayan. Her spouse works as a farmer. To add to the family's income, Jeanne Claire established a water-refilling service in their village, which she has been doing for five years.  She earns about 20,000 PHP. She usually pays 5,000 PHP per month for her chiildren's tuition fees, daily allowances, and meals.

Jeanne Claire is requesting a loan for 15,000 PHP, which she will use to buy more plastic gallons to use in her water refilling service.  She would like to make her business more profitable but she has insufficient funds This loan will help improve her service so that she can meet her customers' demands for clean and safe water. Jeanne Claire hopes to provide a better quality of life for her family.

loans.use: to purchase more plastic gallons to use in her water refilling service.

loans.name: Esmael

texts.en:
Esmael is married and has two children. He is 37 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Esmael is operating a service-based business, providing transportation services to local community members to earn a living. He has been doing this for two years and every month he earns 7,000 PHP from this work. He has requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to repair his existing vehicle so he can provide better service.

Esmael has been a member of GDMPC for three years. In the future, he hopes his children will finish their studies and that he will gain double income  from his business.

loans.use: to repair his existing vehicle so he can provide better service.

loans.name: Sderng

texts.en:
Sderng, 47, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Sderng raises animals and her husband buys rice in bulk to resell. 

Sderng is requesting a loan of USD 750 to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to repair her house.

loans.name: Leonides

texts.en:
45-year-old Leonides earns a living running a tailoring business at her home. She is married and has three school-aged children. Leonides and her family live in the town of Baclayon, Bohol.

Leonides has had her tailoring business for almost ten years. She makes uniforms and provides alterations to clothing. Each month, Leonides earns 15000 PHP with her business.
 
She plans to use her loan to purchase tailoring materials such as cloth, thread, and needles. She will use her profit to pay her children's tuition fees.

loans.use: to purchase tailoring materials such as cloth, thread, and needles.

loans.name: Babi Rahayu Group

texts.en: Because the price for pigs is better now, Ni Ketut decided to ask for a new loan. The loan will be used to purchase two pigs and feed. Ni Ketut said, this business really helps her family to increase their income. Now, it's not only her husband who can work, but she also can help support the family. Her husband very happy about that. She will be saving all the profit for future needs.

loans.use: to buy two pigs.

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Touch, 48, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Touch is a farmer.

Touch is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for the children to commute to work in the city. By doing so, her family is able to decrease expenses on public transportation. 

In the future, she would like to use additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.name: Mawar Merah Group

texts.en:
Rumiati is 43 years old. She is a widow. She just lives with her 18-year-old child who has graduated from school. She has been producing scarves by sewing them herself for two years from her house. The business is going well and new customers come every day. She needs more fabric to produce more scarves and that's why she is taking her first loan with VisionFund Indonesia to buy more fabric and yarn to produce more scarves to sell. 

With the income from her business, she can cover her daily basic needs. She hopes she can have more savings to send her child to university. Also she wants to have a new place to run her business, a more strategic place to reach more customers. 

Other group members will use their loans to improve their businesses such as selling mobile phone refills, running a general store, and selling motorcycle spare parts.

loans.use: to pay for more fabric and yarn to produce scarves to sell.

loans.name: Men

texts.en:
Mrs. Men is 61 years old and a widowed woman who has been living in Kampong Chhnang province. She has spent most her life cultivating rice crops for her livelihood. But this business seems barely enough to satisfy her family, despite daily food. 

Presently, two of her children have started working to help solve and support the family’s financial needs. Her son, Mr. Seth, 24, is acting as a barber in the commune, while the other one is working as a seamstress for a clothes shop in the province. 
 
Mrs. Men feels pity for her son, who is travelling to work by riding a bike. Therefore, she would like to borrow some funds from HKL, a longstanding Kiva partner, to buy a second-hand motorcycle for her son. 

She is very thankful for the support from all lenders.

loans.use: to buy a second-hand motorcycle for her son.

loans.name: Sayragul

texts.ru:
Сайрагуль 43года, замужем.  Муж уехал на заработки в Россию, Сайрагуль живет с дочерью.  
Основная деятельность Сайрагуль – это откорм и перепродажа скота и полеводство.  Начатое еще в 1992 году с суммы в 3,000 сом (KGS) хозяйство, сегодня насчитывает три коровы и тридцать баранов и приносит около 15,000 сом (KGS) в месяц от продажи молочных продуктов.   В данный момент, семья Сайрагуль обрабатывает 2,2 га орошаемой земли , где выращивают картофель и многолетние травы. В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Сайрагуль обратилась в компанию «Бай  Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дополнительного скота. Доходы от кредита Сайрагуль планирует вложить в дальнейшее увеличение количества домашние скотины.
texts.en: Sayragul is 43 years old and married. Her husband went to Russia for work. Sayragul lives with her daughter. Sayragul's main line of work is fatting and reselling cattle and agriculture. She began this in 1992 with an initial investment of 3,000 som; today she has three cows and thirty sheep, bringing in around 15,000 a month from selling dairy products. At this moment, Sayragul's family cultivates 2.2 hectares of irrigated land, where they grow potatoes and perennial grasses. In order to further increase her count of livestock, Sayragul has approached Bai Tushum and Partners for a loan of 50,000 som to purchase additional livestock. With the income from the loan, Sayragul plans to invest in further increasing the number of domestic animals.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Chanthou

texts.en:
Chanthou, 33, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Chanthou is employed at a garment factory. Her husband is a tuk-tuk (motorcycle-based taxi) driver. 

Chanthou is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase a new motorbike for the children to commute to school. By doing so, her family will be able to decrease expenses on public transportation. 

In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for the children to commute to school.

loans.name: Sabiniana

texts.en:
Sabiniana is a married woman from Baclayon, Bohol. She makes and sells "torta" (a baked product popular in the Visayas area). Sabiniana is able to help provide for her family's needs through her business.

Sabiniana has requested this loan to purchase flour, oil, eggs and other ingredients. Sabiniana hopes to have her own bakery someday. She also hopes for her family's living situation to improve.

loans.use: to purchase flour, oil, eggs and other ingredients?

loans.name: Sopheap

texts.en: Sopheap is 40 years old. She is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Sopheap sells food. Sopheap is requesting a loan of USD 700 to purchase two cows to raise for sale. By doing so, her family will be able to generate more income. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy two cows to raise for sale.

loans.name: Mandakh

texts.en:
Mrs. Mandakh, 42 has been working as a headmaster in the secondary school #11 of Dornod, a western region of Mongolia. She lives with her husband and her son in the common.
 
Sometimes she runs a taxi business, using her own car, when she has days off because her monthly salary does not meet her family’s necessary expenses.  She already has permanent customers and earns extra money from her business. 

But lately her car has become old and she needs to change its tires due to the coming winter. In Mongolia there is too much black-frost on the roads in winter. It is very dangerous for her and her customers. Therefore, she needs some money to change her car’s old tires to new winter tires and to make some adjustments to her car.

loans.use: To change her car’s old tires to new winter tires and to make some adjustments to her car.

loans.name: Munkhzul

texts.en:
Mrs. Munkhzul, 47, is widowed and works as a janitress in the secondary school of Kherlen, a western boundary town of Mongolia. She lives with her son, who is a college student. Beyond her job, she rents a small stall for groceries. Her monthly salary does not meet her expenses and she always pays her son’s school fees. 

Munkhzul always wants to expand her sales in order to increase her earnings and save for her son’s education in the future.  First she has a plan to increase her business working capital, such as groceries. 

She thinks that her earnings will be increased when her sales volume is raised. Therefore, the loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchasing a large number of groceries from her suppliers to expand her sales volume.

loans.use: to purchase a large number of groceries from her suppliers to expand her sales volume.

loans.name: Dely Jasmin

texts.en:
Dely Jasmin is a married woman with three children. She is 52 years old and resides at Panaon, Misamis Occidental, Philippines. 

Dely Jasmin owns and operates a farm, planting and harvesting rice to sell to earn a living. She has been in this business for ten years. Each month she earns 8,000 PHP doing this type of business. 

She requested a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. Dely Jasmin has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, she wants to make improvements to her house.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise.

loans.name: Rem

texts.en:
Rem, 63, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. Rem sells morning glories.
 
Rem is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase drinks and groceries for her daughter to sell. By doing so, her family will be able to generate more income.
 
In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy drinks and groceries for her daughter to sell.

loans.name: Ankhzaya

texts.en:
Ankhzaya again needs to renovate her printing machines and add to their number, due to many orders. Lately, she has had a high work load and the number of customers has increased in the last several months.
 
Therefore, she is taking a loan to purchase new Xerox printing machines for equipment renovation of her printing office.

loans.use: to purchase new Xerox printing machines for equipment renovation of her printing office.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma is 47 years old and is a married woman with 2 children aged 19 and 16. Her husband works as a bus aide.

Gemma earns a living by providing manicure and pedicure services to her community. Each month, Gemma earns 3000 PHP. Gemma works hard to help provide for her family. She requested a loan to buy more nail polish, cuticle remover, a nipper and other materials. Gemma hopes to sustain her children's education and help improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more nail polish, cuticle remover, a nipper and other materials.

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en:
Zenaida's primary source of income comes from her business of providing rice milling services in her village. She also sells coconut, flour, and glutinous rice ideal for making suman (glutinous rice desserts). Profits earned from her business are used for daily allowances and meals for the family. 

Through her patience and perseverance, Zenaida sent her five children to college. They are now married and help her financially although she does not like to rely on their assistance.  Therefore, she is requesting a loan for 10,000 PHP, which she will use to buy more coconut and glutinous rice to sell. In the future, Zenaida would like to have good financial management to uplift her family's living condition.

loans.use: to purchase coconut and glutinous rice to sell.

loans.name: Rahmatulo

texts.ru: Рахматуло житель района Яван. Ему 46 лет. Он женат. У него трое детей. Его жена домохозяйка. Сам он занимается разведением крупнорогатого скота. Кредит берет для закупа дойной коровы.
texts.en: Rakmatulo is a resident of the Yavan region. He is married and has three children. His wife is a homemaker. He himself breeds cattle. He is requesting a loan to purchase  a milking cow.

loans.use: purchase  a milking cow

loans.name: Kan

texts.en:
Kan, 52, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. 

Kan and her husband are farmers. Kan is requesting a loan of USD 800 to purchase a motorbike for her children to commute to work. By doing so, her family will be able to reduce how much they spend on public transport. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for her children to commute to work.

loans.name: Querobin

texts.en:
Querobin sells personal products such as cosmetics and shampoo in her village to earn a living. Operating her business for almost five years and earning about PHP2,000 each month, she sells her products mostly to her neighbors. Querobin's profits are just eniough to cover their daily expenses for meals and allowances for her two children.

She is now requesting a loan of PHP10,000 to buy more perfumes, colognes, shampoo and cosmetics to sell, and in the future hopes to earn consistent profits to develop her business and improve the lives of her family.

loans.use: to buy perfumes, colognes, shampoo and cosmetics to sell.

loans.name: Sokim

texts.en:
Sokim, 32, is married and resides with her husband in Takeo Province, Cambodia. 

Kan and her husband sell fish. Sokim is requesting a loan of USD 1000 to purchase more fish to resell. By doing so, her family is able to generate more income. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from KREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: to buy more fish to resell.

loans.name: Rajabek

texts.ru: Рачабек предоставляет услугу, такси. В этой области он уже три года. Ему 23 года. Он женат. У него один ребенок. Он берет кредит для приобретения запчастей автомобиля.
texts.en: Rajabek offers a taxi service. He has been in this line of work for three years already. He is 23, married and has one child. He is requesting a loan to buy spare car parts.

loans.use: buy spare car parts

loans.name: Boobek

texts.ru:
Бообеку 57 лет, воспитал вместе с женой пятерых детей. 
 Бообек работал в сфере сельского хозяйства, сначала водителем, затем разнорабочим., но после распада Советского Союза,  в 1992 году, он организовал  собственное хозяйство и начал заниматься разведением скота и полеводством. Начав с покупки одной коровы, Бообек приложил все усилия для развития своего бизнеса, приносящего на сегодняшний день прибыль в 3,600 сом ежемесячно.  Для дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Бообек обратился в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку двух нетелей. 
В будущем, Бообек планирует расширять поголовье скота и мечтает вместе с младшим сыном построить новый дом.
texts.en: Boobek is 57 and is raising five children with his wife. Boobek worked in agriculture, then as a driver, and then as a laborer. But after the collapse of the Soviet Union, in 1992 he organized his own farm and started raising cattle and growing livestock. Starting with the purchase of one cow, Boobek made every effort to grow his business, bringing in a profit of 3,600 som every month now. To further expand his business, Boobek approached Bai Tushim and Partners for a loan of 50,000 som to purchase two heifers. In the future, Boobek plans to expand the number of cattle and dreams of building a new home with his youngest son.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Dambadarjaa

texts.en:
Dambadarjaa, 59, works as a watchman for a private company. He is also a driver. He worked as a driver for a public organization between 1981-1995 in rural areas, but he left his job due to illness. His salary is often not sufficient for his family's expenses. It is for this reason that he is planning start the taxi business in addition to his job. According to his plans, this will increase his earnings. 

He first needs to purchase a car which is of the standard needed for a taxi service. The loan Dambadarjaa is taking will be used to cover the cost of a car to start his taxi business.

loans.use: To cover the cost of car to start a taxi business.

loans.name: Gnen

texts.en: Mrs. Gnen is a 37-year-old married woman and the mother of 4 single children. She lives and works as a local primary teacher in Kompong Cham province. She is an experienced and skillful teacher. Mrs. Gnen has been engaged in this business since 2000 and typically gets her monthly salary of 80 USD. She doesn’t have any difficulties in her teaching performance, she said, but it’s hard for her to get to work by walking or cycling. So she decided to request a loan from Kiva for the purchase of a motorcycle. She hopes that she will be able to have a comfortable living through using this loan.

loans.use: to purchase a motorcycle

loans.name: Kimyajon

texts.ru: Кимячон жительница города Исфара. Она замужем. Ей 59 лет. У нее двое детей. Она занимается торговлей женской одежды. Этим видом деятельности занимается двадцать лет. Кредит берет для приобретения нового товара.
texts.en: Kimyajon is a resident of the Isfara region. She is married. She is 59 years old and has two children. She sells women's clothes. She has been in this line of work for twenty years. She is requesting a loan to purchase new goods.

loans.use: purchase dresses and turtlenecks

loans.name: Shahnaz

texts.en:
Shahnaz is 33 years old, married and has three sons and a daughter. Her daughter is the youngest one and is three years of age while the others are studying at a nearby school.

Her husband operates a medical store in the market and sells different kinds of medicine to his customers at low rates. He is the only earner in the family and works very hard to put three meals on the table.

Shahnaz is a housewife and performs her household duties by staying at home. She is a very efficient lady and completes her responsibilities with a great sense of responsibility.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s medicine selling business. With the loan investment, he will buy different kinds of medicine such as herbal, homeopathic and allopathic to be able to fulfill the needs of his clients and increase his sales and income.

He is very experienced in his business and has been operating it for many years. Shahnaz is confident that an investment will help her family enjoy more financial benefits by putting her husband’s business in a more profitable position.

loans.use: to buy herbal, allophatic and homeophatic medicines for her husband's medicine selling business.

loans.name: Oleala

texts.en:
Oleala is 24 years old and married with 1 child.

Oleala owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting taro for sale. She has 2 years of experience in this business. She needs a loan of 1,500 WST to purchase weed-killers, such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 WST or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Oleala joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Oleala's second loan with SPBD. 


About  SPBD:

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score".  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Sinavailemalama

texts.en:
Sivavailemalama is 29 years old, married with 4 children.

Sinavailemalama owns and operates a business venture planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has 2 years of experience in this business. Sinavailemalama needs a loan of 1,500 WST to purchase weed-killers, such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 600 WST or US $250 per week) to improve the general living conditions of her family.

In 2010, Sinavailemalama joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Sinavailemalama's second loan with SPBD. 

About  SPBD:

In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and thE. are averaged for the "overall social metric score".  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Nozigul

texts.ru: Нозигул проживает в районе Хамадони. Ей 43 года. Она замужем. У нее шестеро детей. Она арендует торговую точку на рынке, где продает чаку и салаты. В этой области она 10 лет. Кредит берет для покупки помидоров, огурцов, капусты, чаки и зелени.
texts.en: Nozigul lives in the Hamadoni region. She is 43 years old. She is married and has six children. She rents a stall in the market where she sells chuckk and salads. She's been in this line of work for 10 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage, chuck and greens

loans.use: purchase tomatoes, cucumbers, cabbage, chuck and greens

loans.name: Leanie

texts.en:
Leanie, age 43, operates a furniture-making business. She makes and sells general household furniture to local businesses and community members. Leanie has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month. She and her husband live with their two school-aged children in Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. 
 
Leanie is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products. In 2010, Leanie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. Her goal was to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials to manufacture furniture products

loans.name: Mawa B Group

texts.en:
John is the facilitator of the Mawa B group. John and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

John takes care of 15 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, John had a good maize yield, harvesting 7 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  John was only able to harvest 3 ½ bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to John and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, John will invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mawa B group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Ruta Tausolo

texts.en:
Ruta is a married woman, who is 55 years old, and has four kids.

Ruta owns and operates a business venture selling ice cakes and soft drinks. She has two years of experience in this business. Ruta needs a loan of WST 1500. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve the general living conditions of her family.

In 2010, Ruta joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Ruta's second loan with SPBD. 



*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase sugar, milk, and cool aid.

loans.name: Molly

texts.en:
Molly is a married mother, who is 20 years old, with one child.

Molly owns and operates a business venture, driving a taxi.  She has two years of experience in this business.  Molly needs a loan of WST 1500 to maintain her vehicle.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve the general living conditions of her family.

In 2010, Molly joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Molly's second loan with SPBD. 


*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to maintain her vehicle.

loans.name: Nazokat

texts.ru: Назокат замужем. Ей 25 лет. Она имеет средне – специальное образование, продавец. Уже пять лет как она занимается торговлей. В основном Назокат продает детскую и женскую одежду. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота.
texts.en: Nazokat is married, she is 25 years old. She has specialized secondary education, she is a salesperson. She has been in the retail business for five years now. Nazokat mainly sells women's and children's clothing. She is asking for a loan to increase commodity turnover.

loans.use: to increase commodity turnover.

loans.name: Kapeneta

texts.en:
Kapeneta is a married mother, who is 52 years old, and has two kids.

Kaneta owns and operates a business venture, raising pigs for sale.  She has two years of experience in this business.  Kapeneta needs a loan of WST 1500 to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve the general living conditions of her family.

In 2010, Kapeneta joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Kapeneta's second loan with SPBD. 


*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers.  Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score."  For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in the future.

loans.name: Filomena

texts.en:
Filomena, age 30, owns and operates a business venture involving the planting and harvesting of taro. She offers her harvested taro for sale to local community members. She has four years of experience in this business. She lives with her husband and two children in Manono, Samoa. 

Filomena needs a loan of WST $2,500 to purchase harvesting equipment such as wheelbarrows, shovels, rakes, baskets, and knives. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 800 talas or US $333 per week) to improve and expand the business.
 
In 2009, Filomena joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Filomena's fourth loan with SPBD. 



*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Safia is requesting for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s sweetmeat selling business.

With the loan investment, he will buy ingredients such as sugar and cooking oil etc in larger quantities to make better quality and larger quantities of sweetmeat to sell to his clients.
 
The quality and taste of sweetmeat which he provides to his customers is very good, that’s why his products have a high demand among his clients.

Safia is a housewife and performs her household tasks very well. In her spare time she also helps her husband in his business by preparing sweetmeat for him.

She is hopeful that a loan investment will help her husband gain maximum benefit from his business.

Note: “In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Safia.”

loans.name: Bondeni Farmers Group

texts.en:
Wasilwa is the facilitator of the Bondeni Farmers group. Wasilwa and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Wasilwa takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Wasilwa had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Wasilwa was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Wasilwa and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Wasilwa will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Bondeni Farmers group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Nazira

texts.ru: Назира жительница района Конибодом. Возраст, 51 лет. Замужем, имеет одного ребенка. Она имеет среднее образование. Более тридцати лет занимается скотоводством. Она в основном откармливает и продает скот. Кредит берет для закупа несколько голов крупнорогатого скота.

loans.name: Tasleem's Group

texts.en:
Tasleem is 29 years of age and has a 7-year-old son. She lives in a combined family system in a small house with her family and in-laws.

In order to support her family financially, she sells goats and sheep to butchers on order. She purchases these animals from the animal market when they are young. She grows them up by providing them food and then sells to butchers and during the EID festival.

She also operates a clothes-sewing business. She learned the art of sewing from her mother before marriage and now she earns reasonably good income by utilizing her skills.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her animal sales business. With the loan investment, she will buy goats and sheep for selling.

She has been operating her business for many years and is very confident that an investment will help her improve her business further.

loans.use: To buy goats and sheep for the animals sales business.

In 2010, Solinuu joined SPBD* to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Solinuu's second loan with SPBD.

Rolnado would like to improve his output so he is asking for additional capital of PHP 10,000 to buy fertilizers and insecticides used in farming. 

He hopes to make his business more profitable and thus improve his family's living conditions.

loans.name: Amua Shg Group

texts.en:
Gladys is the facilitator of the Amua SHG group. Gladys and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Gladys and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Gladys joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Gladys had a very good maize yield, harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Gladys was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Gladys will invest in livestock rearing and hence save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Amua SHG group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Gladys with her group members, and the person standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
This is Amelia, 62, a resident of GMA, Cavite, Philippines. Her husband is Emmanuel, who is retired.  She and her husband manage their household while operating her business. She works hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.                 
            
Amelia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a small amount of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns profit by buying supplies at wholesale prices and selling at retail. She also sells honey bee products for additional income. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 400 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 17,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages and other products to add to her inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Amelia hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:

Stephen has good credit history with KADET LTD and he is applying for his fourth loan of KES.100,000.  He plans to use this loan to buy more curios to sell. He will use the anticipated profit to expand his business. In the future, Stephen hopes to open a new shop. He is very hardworking.

loans.use: to buy additional curios to sell.

loans.name: Navruz

texts.ru: Навруз житель района Хамадони. Ему 32 года. Он женат. У них пятеро детей. Навруз занимается торговлей. Он продает яблоки. Этим видом бизнеса занимается четыре года. Кредит берет для покупки фруктов.
texts.en: Navruz is a residents of Hamadoni region. He is 32 years old, married and has five children. Navruz sells apples. He has been in this business for four years. He is taking out the loan to buy fruits.

loans.use: to buy fruits.

loans.name: Naomi

texts.en:
Naomi is married and she's 46 years of age with 9 children.

Naomi owns and operates a business venture, selling baked goods in the local community. She has 2 years of experience in this business. Naomi needs a loan of WST $1500 to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 450 talas or US $188 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Naomi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Naomi's 2nd loan with SPBD. 



*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the ""overall social metric score.""  For example, a 3 out of 3 on ""level of education"" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About  SPBD 
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific.  SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.  "

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale.

loans.name: Fofoa

texts.en:
Fofoa, age 67, plants and harvests taro and offers her harvested produce for sale. She has many years of experience in this business. Fofoa needs a loan of WST $1,500 to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family. She and her husband have raised seven children.
 
In 2010, Fofoa joined SPBD* to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Fofoa's second loan with SPBD. 
 
*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About SPBD:
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on Kiva to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.name: Batorgil

texts.en:
Batorgil, age 44, started his water delivery service in 2003, transporting his wares by horse and carriage. He is one of only two people in the district who deliver water and therefore has many customers. The carriage, however, is old and currently unable to operate. Batorgil is requesting 1,300,000 MNT to make necessary repairs to his carriage as well as to store up some food for his horse during the winter.

He is a sharp and hardworking man who lives with his wife and two children in a "ger" (a Mongolian yurt) in Bulgan province, Mongolia. His wife is employed as a janitor. Their eldest child is a college student and the younger one is enrolled is school.

loans.use: to make necessary repairs to his carriage as well as to store up some food for his horse during the winter

loans.name: Marata

texts.en:
Marata, age 54, provides alteration and tailoring services to local community members. She has four years of experience in this business. Marata needs a loan of WST $2,000 to purchase additional fabrics and materials. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand the business. She and her husband have four children.
 
In 2007, Marata joined SPBD* in order to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Marata's fifth loan with SPBD. 
 
*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.  

About SPBD:
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD to improve the quality of life of people living in poverty in the poor island nations of the South Pacific. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based on a respect for each individual's innate human ingenuity, drive and self esteem. Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD.

loans.use: to purchase fabrics and materials

loans.name: Fe

texts.en:
Fe, age 47, earns a living by raising pigs for sale. Fe has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities. Fe and her husband live in Sinacaban, Misamis Occidental. They have two adult children. 
  
Fe is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future. In 2010, Fe joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her business and living situation. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell in future

loans.name: Tagi

texts.en:
Tagi, age 32, earns her living by selling dairy products in the local community. She has two years of experience in this business. Tagi needs a loan of WST $1,000 to purchase additional products to sell. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 200 talas or US $83 per week) to improve and expand the business. She and her husband have two children.
 
Earlier this year, Tagi joined SPBD* to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Tagi's first loan with SPBD. 

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

loans.name: Oyundelger

texts.en: Oyundelger, 44, lives with her husband and two children in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bulgan province, Mongolia. Her husband is a taxi driver, her elder daughter is a nurse and her younger one is a school student. She started her meat retailing business in 2000 by renting a counter in the market. Now she also owns a small food court. Her food court business is going pretty well, therefore she wants to buy raw materials for the business. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who is requesting 500,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) to buy food materials.

loans.use: to buy food materials.

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen is a widow. Her husband died leaving her alone but she never lost hope and started a beauty parlor business at her home. She is an expert beautician and provides good quality services to her clients who are mostly women from her community.

She has given birth to three sons and a daughter. All of them are enrolled in local school and are receiving their education. Yasmeen works very hard to afford their school fees. She is a great mother and raises her children very well.

She has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further improvement of her parlor business. With the loan investment, she will buy some furniture to increase the sitting arrangements at her parlor. She will also buy makeup material such as nail polishes, mascaras, eye shadows etc. This will help her to provide better quality customer services and increase her profits.

She has been operating her business for sometime now and is hopeful that an investment will be a productive one for her and she will be able to continue providing education for her children.

loans.use: to buy nail polishes, mascaras, eye shadows and furniture for her beauty parlor business.

loans.name: Juakali Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Juakali Group in Western Kenya! Rose is the facilitator of the Juakali group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Rose  takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Rose had a very good maize yield, harvesting 14 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Rose was only able to harvest 5 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rose  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Rose will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Juakali group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Tafu Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Tafu SHG Group in Western Kenya! Miriam is the facilitator of the Tafu SHG group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Miriam takes care of 10 children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and access more technology in food production to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Miriam had a very good maize yield, harvesting 10 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Miriam was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Miriam and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Miriam will educate her children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Tafu SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Miriam with her group members, and the person standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Armando

texts.en:
Armando, 27, is single and lives in Jiminez, in the province of Misamis Occidental, Philippines. He operates a service-based business, providing transportation services to local community members to earn a living. He has been doing this for one year and every month he earns 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from this work. 

Armando has requested a loan of 5,000 PHP to repair a transport vehicle used in his business. He has been a member of GDMPC for a year. In the future, he hopes to improve the general living conditions of his family.

loans.use: to repair a transport vehicle used in his business.

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora, 24, is married woman with two children, aged two and six, one of whom is in school. She has had a pub business in Kator, South Sudan for three years.

Flora requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase beer for her pub. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house and pay her child's school fees in the future.

loans.use: to purchase beer and local alcohol for resale.

loans.name: Tepalua

texts.en:
Tepalua, 48, is married with six children. She owns and operates a business venture selling traditional handicrafts to tourists and local community members. She has two years of experience in this business. Tepalua needs a loan of $1500 Samoan Talas (WST) to purchase additional handicrafts to sell. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or $167 US per week) to make improvements to her house.

Tepalua joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Tepalua's second loan with SPBD.

*SPBD evaluates the living conditions of each of its borrowers. Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." For example, a 3 out of 3 on "level of education" would mean that the borrower has graduated from university.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia, 38, is married to James and they are blessed with three children, who are school going. She operates a school in Githurai 44. She has been in this business for the last seven years and earns an income of 15,000 Kenyan Shillings (KES) per month.

Lucia has a good credit history in KADET and she is applying for her third loan of 80,000 KES, which she plans to use to renovate the school and buy textbooks. She will use the extra profit to educate her children.

Lucia hopes to expand the business. She is very hardworking.

loans.use: to renovate the school and buy textbooks.

loans.name: Melipa

texts.en:
Melipa, 42, is married with five children. She is starting a business venture, selling pancakes in her village and needs a loan of $1000 Samoan Talas (WST) to purchase flour,sugar, cooking oil and a frying pan. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or $146 US per week) to improve and expand the business.

Melipa joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Melipa's first loan with SPBD.

loans.name: Safarali

texts.ru: Сафарали проживает в районе Яван. Ему 25 лет. Он Холост. Живет вместе с родителями. У него высшее образование. По профессии он программист. На сегодняшний день по профессии он не работает. У него имеется собственный магазин, где он продает музыкальные диски, mp3 и DVD. Кроме того Сафарали продает запасные части мобильных телефонов. В этой области он два года. Кредит берет для увеличения ассортимента товара.
texts.en: Safarali lives in the Yavan region. He is 25 years old and a bachelor. He lives together with his parents. He has high eduction with the degree in programming. Right now he does not work in his professional field. He has own store where he sells music compact disks, mp3 and DVD's. Besides that Safarali sells spare parts for mobile phones. He has been in this business for two years. He is taking out the loan to increase the variety of his merchandise.

loans.use: to buy new compact disks.

loans.name: Byambajav

texts.en:
Byambajav, 26, lives with her two brothers in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Dornod province, Mongolia. Her elder brother is a herder and her younger one is a college student. 

Byambajav started her hairdressing business in 2005 by renting a space in the market. Since starting her business, she has become well experienced and has many customers. However, her hairdressing equipment is getting old, therefore she is requesting a loan of 700,000 Mongolian Tugriks (MNT) to buy equipment from Ulaanbaatar.

loans.use: to buy equipment from Ulaanbaatar.

loans.name: Luaao

texts.en:
Luaao is a married mother, she is 66 years old, and has 12 children.

Luaao owns and operates a business venture, planting and harvesting bananas for sale. She has three years of experience in this business. Luaao needs a loan of WST $1900.00 to purchase additional seeds, seedlings, and young crops to raise. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2009, Luaao joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral. This is Luaao's third loan with SPBD.

Generally, a loan manager evaluates a variety of social metrics on a scale out of 3 (the higher the number, the better off the person is) and these are averaged for the "overall social metric score." loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en: Fatuma is a 32-year-old married woman with five children between the ages of four and eighteen years. Three of them are in school. She has a business of selling food in a hotel in Kator, South Sudan for four years. Fatuma requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase rice and beans. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children in future.

loans.use: to purchase rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Punsalmaa

texts.en: Punsalmaa is a 47-year-old widowed mother of one who lives with her son in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bulgan Province, Mongolia. Her son is a school student. She started her small commodity retailing business in 2001 by selling items in the streets. She sells souvenirs, strings, toys, etc. Now that she is the only one with the income in the family, she rented a counter in a market. However, she needs a supply to run a business. She is a strong and hard-working woman who says, "It's been hard since my husband died, however I will never give up and I will do everything I can to support my son." She is requesting 500,000 MNT to buy more supplies to sell.

loans.use: To buy more supplies to sell

loans.name: Ufanisi Group

texts.en:
Henry is the facilitator of the Ufanisi group. Henry and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Henry takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and in order to ensure food security for his kids. In the recent 2011 season, Henry had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 12 ½ bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Henry was only able to harvest 3 ½ bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Henry and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Henry will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Ufanisi group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Luse

texts.en:
Luse, 30, is a married mother of four children.

Luse owns and operates a business venture, raising pigs for sale. She has two years of experience in this business.    

Luse needs a loan of WST 1,000 to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 300 WST or US $125 per week) to improve and expand the business.

Luse joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Luse's third loan with SPBD.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline's priority in life is to uplift her family's living conditions. She has four children attending school and needs to pay for their daily allowances. She wants to earn consistent profits for their education. She described herself as a small entrepreneur, yet a hardworking woman. She raise hogs to fatten and breed and usually sells them to butchers who come into her village. She earns about PHP 3,000 whenever she sells a raised hog. 

She wants to improve her business, that is why she is asking for additional capital to provide good nutrition for her hogs. She is now asking for a loan of PHP 25,000 to buy hog feeds, vitamins and medicines. This loan will help her grow her hogs and be able to sell them at a higher cost upon distribution. 

In the future, she hopes to improve her pigpen and maintain the safety and good growth of her hogs and also to continuously educate her children.

loans.use: to buy feed, vitamins and medicines to ensure the good nutrition of her hogs.

loans.name: Jovito

texts.en:
Jovito is a married man with three children.  He is 41 years old and he has one and half hectares of family farm land.  Jovito generates income through planting and harvesting corn for sale.  His wife also manages their sari-sari store based in their home for extra income.  They both work hard just to keep their children from poor living standards. 

At this time, Jovito wants to borrow PHP 30,000 to purchase farm input such as fertilizers and corn seedlings.  In the future, he is hoping to grow his business for the betterment of the family's daily living.

loans.use: to purchase farm input such as fertilizers and corn seedlings.

Vaiola owns and operates a business venture, selling snacks and other delicacies in the local community. She has two years of experience in this business. loans.name: Battsetseg

texts.en:
Battsetseg is 36 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Bulgan province, Mongolia. 

Her husband is employed, her elder two children are school students and the younger one goes to kindergarten. 

She started her stationery retailing business in 1998 by renting a counter in the market. Now that her business is stable, she decided to extend her market space by renting another counter in a market. However, her supplies are not enough to run a whole counter. Therefore she is requesting 2,500,000 MNT to purchase more supplies. 

She is a sharp and diligent woman who says, "My kids are growing. Therefore more and more money is required to support them.  I have to do everything I can in order to support them."

loans.use: To purchase more stationery supplies.

loans.name: Muungano B Group

texts.en:
Abraham is the facilitator of the Muungano B group. Abraham and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Abraham takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to improve food production and hence ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Abraham had a very good maize yield, harvesting 7 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Abraham was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on ½ an acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Abraham and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Abraham will educate his children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Muungano B group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Abraham is pictured with his group members and standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Elmer

texts.en:
Elmer is from the village of Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. He is 42 years old. Elmer is married and has four school-aged children. 

To make a living, Elmer owns and operates a business venture, selling liquor such as beer and wine in the local community. Elmer has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Elmer is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. 

In 2010, Elmer joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his business and living situation. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the loan to improve and expand his business.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy materials for the tailoring business.

loans.name: Rehana's Group

texts.en:
Rehana is a very loving and caring lady and always thinks positively for her family.  Although she is not financially supporting her family, she takes care of her family very well and tries to give comfort to them with her efforts.
She is the mother of four children.  Her first two sons are electricians by profession and operate an electric shop in the community.  They provide the services of repairing and selling electric items to the customers.
They have very good clientage and they serve them respectfully.
Rehana is requesting a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her second son.  He will use the loan to buy electric items such as tube lights, electric wires, bulbs, etc.  Selling these items will allow him to increase his profits.  He will also buy repairing tools which will allow him to provide better quality repairing services to his customers. 
She is very confident that her son will make full use of the loan amount and will be able to gain maximum profits from his business.

loans.use: To buy tube lights, electric bulbs, and repairing tools for an electric items sales and repair business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy bags, clothes and vegetables.

loans.name: Entelic

texts.en: Entelic is a 27-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of three and fourteen years. All of them are in school. She has had a business of selling beer in Kator, South Sudan for two years. Entelic requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase beer. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children in the future.

loans.use: to purchase beer for sale.

loans.name: Richard

texts.en:
Richard is 33 years old.  He is married and has three school-aged children.  They live in Angadanan, Isabela where he manages their corn field.  He has been doing his farming business for ten years.  Richard only received P3,000 with his last crop because of an unexpected typhoon.  His wife also engages in a hog-raising business for extra income.  They are both thankful because the income they generate from their businesses helps them to provide daily needs and to be able to send their children to school.

Right now, Richard is requesting a loan of P40,000 to purchase corn seedlings and fertilizers for his farming business.  He hopes that he can get the amount he requested and he is promising to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: to purchase corn seedlings and fertilizers for his farming business.

loans.name: Tserenhand

texts.en:
Tserenhand is 33 years old and lives with her husband and son in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bulgan province, Mongolia. Her husband is a truck driver and her son is a school student. 

She started her hairdressing business in 2004 by renting a space in the market. Her hairdressing is stylish and inexpensive. Now that her business is stable, she wants to buy additional equipment to expand her business. She is a sharp and hardworking woman who says "I am losing my customers due to my equipment". She is requesting 650,000 MNT to buy equipment.

loans.use: To buy equipment to expand her business.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy weaves, braids and wigs.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a 53 year old married woman residing in Sta. Cruz, Jiminez, Misamis Occidental: Philippines. 

Josephine owns and operates a, planting & harvesting rice for sale to earn a living. She's been 15 years in this business. Each month, she earns  Php10,000 doing this type of business. 

Josephine has requested a loan of 20,000.00 to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise. Josephine has been a member of GDMPC for almost a year. In the future, Josephine wants to make improvements on her house and to purchase a transport vehicle for use in her business.

loans.use: to purchase additional seeds, seedlings & young crops to raise
